questions.text: Jod-Basedow phenomenon is best described by:

choices.text: Hyperthyroidism following increased intake of iodine
Hypothyroidism following increased intake of iodine
Hyperthyroidism following decreased intake of iodine
Hypothyroidism following decreased intake of iodine

questions.solution:
Jod-Basedow phenomenon is iodide-induced hyperthyroidism. 

Note: For remembering purpose; consider Jod-Basedow phenomenon as an opposite effect of Wolff-Chaikoff effect. 

In normal and hyperthyroid individuals, acute intake of higher doses of iodides will decrease the thyroid hormone synthesis and release: Wolff-Chaikoff effect.

In susceptible individuals, the Wolff-Chaikoff effect is not seen but ingested iodide induces hyperthyroidism. The most plausible pathology is that the thyroid hormone secretion in such individuals is not primarily dependent on TSH.

Jod-Basedow phenomenon is commonly seen in susceptible individuals who migrate from iodine deficient regions to regions where iodine supply is normal. It can also be seen in patients receiving drugs having high iodine content like iodinated contrast media especially in the elderly.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes Milroy disease?
questions.solution:
Milroy disease refers to heredofamilial congenital lymphedema.

Causes of lymphedema:

Primary lymphedema:

  • Simple congenital lymphedema
  • Heredofamilial congenital lymphedema (Milroy disease)

Secondary or obstructive lymphedema:

  • Malignant tumors obstructing lymphatic channels
  • Surgical removal of regional groups of lymph nodes, e.g., radical mastectomy
  • Postirradiation fibrosis
  • Filariasis
  • Post-inflammatory thrombosis and scarring

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant with progressive failure to thrive and milestone regression is being evaluated for an inborn error of metabolism. On examination, hypotonia, apathy, deafness, hepatosplenomegaly, and generalized lymphadenopathy are present. Fundus examination is shown below. A liver biopsy shows foamy hepatocytes loaded with sphingomyelin. Electron microscopy reveals zebra bodies. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Progressive failure to thrive, milestone regression, hypotonia, apathy, deafness, hepatosplenomegaly, and generalized lymphadenopathy with the cherry-red spot on fundus examination suggests a diagnosis of Niemann-Pick disease type A.

 Niemann-Pick disease is a lysosomal storage disorder due to an inherited deficiency of sphingomyelinase. This results in the accumulation of sphingomyelin in the monocyte-macrophage system. Type A disease is a severe infantile form. Infants present with extensive neurologic involvement (hypotonia, milestone regression, apathy), marked visceral accumulations of sphingomyelin (hepatosplenomegaly, foamy hepatocytes, zebra bodies on EM), progressive wasting and early death within the first 3 years of life.

In contrast, patients with Niemann-Pick disease type B have organomegaly but generally no CNS involvement.

questions.text: Abhi, a young boy is being evaluated in the ward for proximal muscle weakness. Waddling gait and Gowers sign are observed in this child. Genetic analysis confirms the diagnosis as Duchenne muscular dystrophy. Which of the following is false regarding this patient's condition?

choices.text: It is less severe than Becker's dystrophy
Tendon reflexes are lost after age 6
Gene affected is the largest gene in humans

questions.solution:
Duchenne muscular dystrophy is more severe than Becker’s dystrophy. In DMD, tendon reflexes are lost after age 6.

Becker’s dystrophy is similar to Duchenne muscular dystrophy with a genetic defect at the same locus (Xp21) but clinically less severe. Gene affected in both is dystrophin, which is the largest gene in humans.

Important differences between Duchenne and Becker’s muscular dystrophy:

Weakness Progressive Variable
Intellectual impairment Common Uncommon
Prognosis Wheelchair dependant by adolescence Ambulatory till early adult life
Death By the age of 18–20 years By 40s or 50s

questions.text: You are examining a case of goitre and observe that it moves with deglutition. The movement occurs due to the attachment of the thyroid gland by Berry's ligament, to which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
The movement of the thyroid gland with deglutition is due to the attachment of Berry's ligament to the cricoid cartilage.

Ligament of Berry:

The pretracheal fascia encloses the thyroid gland to form its false capsule. This capsule is thickened posteriorly and on either side forms a suspensory ligament which is known as ligament of Berry or lateral thyroid ligament. The posteromedial aspects of the lobes of the thyroid are attached to the side of the cricoid cartilage by the ligament of Berry. It also prevents the thyroid gland from sinking into the mediastinum.

Related Pearl: Modifications of Deep cervical fascia

The deep fascia in the neck is condensed to form the following layers:

Investing layer - It forms the roof of the posterior triangle and splits to enclose:

  • Parotid gland
  • Submandibular gland

Pretracheal fascia - It splits to enclose the thyroid gland to form its false capsule. This capsule is thickened posteriorly and on either side forms the suspensory ligament which is known as the ligament of Berry.

Carotid sheath - is formed anteriorly by pre tracheal fascia and posteriorly by the prevertebral fascia. It encloses:

  • Common carotid artery
  • Internal carotid artery
  • Internal jugular vein
  • Vagus nerve 

Prevertebral fascia - It forms the floor of the posterior triangle and the axillary sheath. Inferiorly, it blends with the anterior longitudinal ligament.

Buccopharyngeal fascia - It covers the outer surface of the pharyngeal constrictors and the buccinator. Posteriorly, it's separated from the prevertebral fascia by the retropharyngeal space.

Pharyngobasilar fascia - It fills the gap between superior constrictor and base of the skull.

questions.text: Haab’s striae is due to tears in:
questions.solution:
Haab's striae are curvilinear healed breaks in Descemet membrane seen in case of buphthalmos (congenital glaucoma). These occur because Descemet’s membrane is less elastic than corneal stroma. It is seen as double 'tram-track' lines concentric to the limbus.

Tears are:

  • Usually peripheral
  • Concentric with the limbus
  • Appear as lines with double contour

Note: Vogt's striae are vertical (rarely horizontal) fine, whitish lines in the deep/posterior stroma and Descemet's membrane commonly found in patients with keratoconus.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl presents with skin lesions as shown in the image. The parents also complain of early breast development, growth acceleration, and vaginal bleeding. On genetic studies, it was found that there is a gain of function mutation of G Protein. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the most probable diagnosis is McCune-Albright syndrome as it is the only gain-of-function mutation of G Protein.

G proteins or G protein-coupled receptor complexes can undergo a loss- or gain-of-function mutation. Some examples are given below:

Receptor Type of mutation Disease
Cone opsin Loss Colour blindness
Rhodopsin Loss Night blindness or retinitis pigmentosa
Endothelin receptor Loss Hirschsprung disease
TSH receptor Loss Familial hypothyroidism
TSH receptor Gain Familial hyperthyroidism
LH receptor Gain Familial male precocious puberty
Gs protein Gain Pituitary adenomas with acromegaly
Gs protein Gain (mosaic) McCune-Albright syndrome

In McCune-Albright syndrome, a gain-of-function mutation in Gsα is associated with the rough-bordered areas of skin pigmentation and hypercortisolism. This mutation occurs during fetal development, creating a mosaic of normal and abnormal cells.

questions.text: What does Ribot’s law deal with?
questions.solution:
Ribot's law deals with retrograde amnesia.

During incidents of retrograde amnesia, most recently acquired memories are the most vulnerable to disruption from brain damage. This temporal gradation of retrograde amnesia that preferentially spares the more distant memories is known as Ribot's law.

E.g: If an incident causing retrograde amnesia occurs at 30 years of age, the memories acquired at 25 years of age may be more severely affected than those memories acquired at 20 years of age or earlier.

questions.text: While assessing the quality of drinking water in a village, you detect the presence of coliform bacilli by the multiple tube technique. Following this, you decide to perform the Eijkman test. What is this test also known as?
questions.solution:
Eijkman test is also known as differential coliform test. 

Drinking water should be free of any pathogenic microorganisms. The presence of coliform bacteria in the water may indicate faecal pollution, while the detection of E.coli confirms it. The presumptive coliform test is done by the multiple-tube technique. Following this, the Eijkman test is done to confirm the presence of E. coli. They can grow at 44°C (faecal thermotolerant bacilli), ferment lactose and cause indole and gas production.

In this test, the bottles of the presumptive coliform test showing acid and gas are subcultured to tubes of single-strength MacConkey medium, which are then incubated at 44°C. After 24 hours, tubes with gas are said to have E. Coli. The number of bacteria present in the water sample is determined using McCrady's probability tables.

Option A: Presumptive coliform count detects the probable number of coliform bacilli in water. It can be positive due to the presence of organisms other than E.coli.

Option C: Colony counts provide an estimate of the general bacterial purity of water.

Option D: Methylene blue reduction test is used to assess the bacterial contamination of milk.

questions.text: Hysterical pseudodementia is a type of ____?
questions.solution:
Ganser syndrome (hysterical pseudodementia) is a type of dissociative disorder.

It is commonly found in prison inmates. The characteristic feature is vorbeireden, which is also called approximate answers. The answers are incorrect but show that the person understands the nature of the question asked. E.g., when asked about the color of an apple, the patient's answer is blue.

questions.text: A worried mother brought her 4-year-old son to the ER with complaints of a nose bleed. On examination, the bleed was found to be from the Kiesselbach’s plexus. Which of the following arteries does not contribute to its formation?
questions.solution:
The posterior ethmoidal artery does not contribute to the formation of Kiesselbach’s plexus.

Kiesselbach’s plexus is the vascular anastomosis situated at Little’s area (anteroinferior part of the septum).

The contributing arteries are as follows:

  • Sphenopalatine and greater palatine branches of the maxillary artery, which in turn is a branch of the external carotid artery.
  • Septal branch of the superior labial artery which in turn is a branch of the facial artery. The facial artery is a branch of the external carotid artery.
  • Anterior ethmoidal branch of the ophthalmic division of internal carotid artery.

The posterior ethmoidal artery is a branch of the ophthalmic division of internal carotid artery, which supplies nasal septum but does not contribute to Kiesselbach’s plexus.

This question was asked in recent AIIMS and NEET examinations, making it a potential repeat.

questions.text: Hartnup’s disease causes a deficiency of _______
questions.solution:
• Hartnup’s disease causes a deficiency state of niacin.
  • It is Autosomal recessive caused by mutations in the SLC6A19 gene.
  • It is characterized by impaired absorption of the amino acid tryptophan.
  • As a result of the reduced levels of tryptophan, there is lesser conversion to niacin. This leads to a state of niacin deficiency.

questions.text: A 54-year-old male presents with an ulcer on his hand. On swab culture, growth of M. ulcerans is seen. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Mycobacterium ulcerans causes Buruli ulcer. 

M. ulcerans produces a toxin called mycolactone which leads to formation of Buruli ulcer. This is a chronic, debilitating, necrotizing disease of the skin and soft tissue which is characterized by the formation of ulcers that progressively enlarge over time if left untreated. The ulcers heal with disfiguring scars.

The image below shows a Buruli ulcer. 

 

Option A: Hunner's ulcers are seen in a subset of patients with interstitial cystitis. These are areas of inflammation on the bladder wall. 

The image below shows a cystoscopic image of a Hunner's ulcer.

 

Option B: Meleney's ulcer or post-operative synergistic bacterial gangrene occurs in immuno-compromised individuals following abdominal surgery. It is caused by a synergistic interaction between microaerophilic nonhemolytic Streptococcus and hemolytic aerobic Staphylococcus aureus.

Option D: Marjolin ulcer is a rare and aggressive form of squamous cell carcinoma that grows from burns, scars, or poorly healing wounds. 

The image below shows a Marjolin's ulcer in a burn scar.

questions.text: A 28-year-old lifeguard presents to the dermatology clinic with a mildly pruritic lesion as shown for 8 days. History reveals excessive use of perfumes. Which of the following can be the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a deep‐brown pigmented lesion in the right underarm likely to have formed from the trickle of the droplets of perfume applied on the skin. This is suggestive of Berloque dermatitis.

The skin pigmentation occurs due to an acute phototoxic reaction to perfumes containing bergamot oil (bergapten) which potentiates UV‐stimulated melanogenesis. A hot and humid climate along with exposure to UV light increases the risk of developing this condition.

questions.text: What does Billing's method of contraception refer to?
questions.solution:
Billing’s method of contraception refers to the cervical mucus method. It is also called ovulation method.

The properties of the cervical mucus change during the menstrual cycle. The female partner can predict the fertile period by examining her cervical mucus.

Under the influence of estrogen, the mucus increases in quantity and becomes more slippery and elastic i.e. wet days. This continues till it reaches a peak. After this, under the influence of progesterone, it becomes thicker, scanty i.e. dry days.

Abstinence is advised during the wet days till 4 days after the peak day. The safe period includes the dry days after menses till the appearance of mucus and from the 4th day after the peak day. 

The pattern of cervical mucus secretion during a menstrual cycle is given below.

questions.text: A mother brought her 7-month-old infant with concerns of abnormal eye movements and developmental delay. MRI was done and is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The axial T1-weighted MRI shows molar tooth sign at the level of superior cerebellar peduncles. Given the clinical presentation and radiological findings, the diagnosis is Joubert syndrome. 

This autosomal recessive neurological disorder is characterised by cerebellar vermis hypoplasia and is associated with hypotonia, developmental delay, ataxia, irregular breathing patterns, and abnormal eye movements.

questions.text: Which of the following factors in a study will cause Berkesonian bias?

choices.text: Interviewer asking leading questions to the subjects
Different rates of hospital admission of different diseases
Researcher's belief in the treatment changing the outcome of the study
Cases that are lost to follow-up

questions.solution:
Berkesonian bias occurs due to the different rates of hospital admission of people with different diseases. It is a type of selection bias termed after Joseph Berkeson who described it.

Related Pearl: Bias in Epidemiological Studies

Type of Bias Definition Methods to reduce it
Observer bias Differential ability to observe. A subjective bias.  
Interviewer's bias Interviewer asking leading questions to the subjects. Or interviewing cases thoroughly than the controls.  Double blinding
Memory/ Recall bias Differential ability of cases and controls to recall a certain detail. An objective bias. Decrease time from exposure to follow-up
Surveillance bias Active surveillance leads to an increased chance of identifying the event.  
Reporting/ notification bias Diseases associated with stigma are reported less.  
Berkesonian bias Hospital-based case-control studies. Occurs due to differential hospital admission rates.

Randomization or Matching 
Selection bias A sampling bias. Non-random allocation of subjects that do not represent the population Randomization or Matching
Hawthorne bias Change in attitude/ actions of the subjects under observation Use placebo group
Confounding bias Factors related to both exposure and outcome distort the effect of exposure on outcome Matching, cross-over studies, randomization, or stratification
Attrition bias Participants lost to follow-up have a different prognosis than those who complete the study. Randomization
Pygmalion bias Researcher's high expectations in the efficacy of the treatment change the outcome of that treatment. Blinding
Neyman's/ Prevalence-Incidence bias  Occurs due to the selective survival in prevalent cases usually seen in fatal diseases. Very sick patients are automatically excluded because of their early death.  

Neyman’s bias or prevalence-incidence bias example: a case-control study is carried out to study the relationship between tobacco smoking and acute myocardial infarction (AMI). The cases are interviewed one week after the coronary attack. If smoker patients with AMI die more frequently, the living cases will show a lower frequency of smoking, undervaluing the association between smoking and AMI. It has been shown that the bias occurs only if the risk factor influences mortality from the disease being studied.

Ecological fallacy results when characteristics of the group are assigned inappropriately to individuals.

questions.text: A patient with sarcoidosis shows Koeppe's nodules on ophthalmologic examination. Where are these seen?
questions.solution:
Koeppe's nodules and Bussaca's nodules develop on the iris in granulomatous uveitis.

Granulomatous uveitis is a chronic proliferative inflammation seen in reponse to tuberculosis, leprosy, syphilis and sarcoidosis. Infiltration of lymphocytes and plasma cells, with proliferation of mononuclear cells leads to the formation of iris nodule. Koeppe's nodules are seen at the pupillary margin. Bussaca's nodules are seen on the peripheral part of the anterior surface of iris.

questions.text: Renshaw cell inhibition is ________
questions.solution:
Renshaw cell inhibition is an example of feedback inhibition.

The axon of a spinal motor neuron has a recurrent collateral that synapses on an inhibitory interneuron that terminates on the cell body of the same and other motor neurons. The inhibitory interneuron is called a Renshaw cell and its neurotransmitter is glycine.

questions.text: Extensive fibrosis is a characteristic feature of which thyroiditis?
questions.solution:
Riedel thyroiditis is a rare disorder characterised by extensive fibrosis of thyroid gland and adjacent structures.

It may be associated with retroperitoneal fibrosis and appears to be another manifestation of a systemic autoimmune IgG4 related disease.

Clinical significance: Hard and fixed thyroid mass may mimic Carcinoma.

questions.text: What is the maneuver depicted in the image given below?
questions.solution:
The given image shows Trotter’s method in which the patient is made to sit, leaning a little forward over a basin to spit any blood and breathe quietly from the mouth. It is the first step to control epistaxis.

Other options:

Option A: Epley’s maneuver is used in the treatment of BPPV (Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo).

Option C: McGovern’s technique is used in choanal atresia. A feeding nipple with a large hole provides a good oral airway.

Option D: Valsalva maneuver is performed by forceful attempted exhalation against a closed nose and mouth. It is used as a test of cardiac function and autonomic nervous control of the heart, or to clear the ears and sinuses.

questions.text: The given CT finding is associated with which of the following genodermal disorders?
questions.solution:
The CT brain shows tram-track cortical calcifications, a characteristic feature of Sturge-Weber syndrome.

It occurs due to leptomeningeal hemangioma, resulting in a vascular steal affecting the subjacent cortex and white matter producing localized ischemia and calcification.

Related Pearl: Tram Track Appearance in Various Conditions

Tram tracks or tram track signs are medical signs that bear some resemblance to tramway tracks (Railway Track).

1. Pulmonology

  • When found in the lungs, tram tracks are radiologic signs that are usually accompanied by pulmonary edema in cases of congestive heart failure and bronchiectasis.
  • Tram tracks are caused by bronchial wall thickening, and can be detected on a lateral chest X-ray.

2. Nephrology

  • The term "tram tracks" is also used to describe the basement membrane duplication found on light microscopy that is characteristic of membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) type I.
  • It is less commonly associated with types II and III.

3. Neurology

  • The term has also been used to describe findings associated with optic nerve sheath meningioma.
  • Tram track-shaped calcifications in the cerebral cortex indicate Sturge-Weber syndrome.

4. Mammary glands:

  • Tram track appearance in mammography/USG indicates Duct Ectasia.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions present with Horner Trantas dots?
questions.solution:
Horner Trantas dots are seen in vernal keratoconjunctivitis. They appear as white dots at the limbus of the cornea. These white dots contain eosinophils and epithelial cellular debris.

Other options:

  • Phlyctenular keratoconjunctivitis: 
    • Type 4 hypersensitivity reaction 
    • Due to endogenous allergens like Staphylococcus aureus (most common) and Mycobacterium tuberculosis
    • Characterized by the following:
      • Phlycten
      • May eventually form ring ulcers
      • Scrofulous ulcer: shallow marginal ulcer due to the breakdown of limbal phlycten
      • Fascicular ulcer: It has a prominent parallel leash of blood vessels. It heals leaving a band-shaped opacity.
  • Giant papillary conjunctivitis:
    • The severe form of mechanically induced papillary conjunctivitis is known as giant papillary conjunctivitis (GPC).
    • It is most frequently encountered with contact lens (CL) wear; in such cases, it is termed contact lens-associated papillary conjunctivitis (CLPC). 
    • It may be caused by ocular prostheses, exposed sutures, and scleral buckles, corneal surface irregularity, or filtering blebs.
  • Lyell syndrome: It is a form of toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN)

questions.text: Which of the following indices of obesity is obtained by dividing weight in kg by square of height in metres?
questions.solution:
Quetelet's index (Body Mass Index) is obtained by dividing weight in kg by square of height in metres.

Related Pearl: Indicators for Body fat

The indicators for body fat are:

Body weight: +3SD (standard deviations) from the median weight for height as a cut-off point for obesity. For adults, some people calculate various other indicators such as:

  • Body mass index (Quetelet's index): Weight (kg) / Square of height in metres
  • Ponderal index: Weight (kg)/Height^3 (m)
  • Corpulence index: Actual weight /desirable weight.(Should not exceed 1.2)

Broca's index = Height (cm) - 100 . 

Lorentz's formula 
Ht (cm) - 100 - [ (Ht (cm) - 150) / 2 for women or 4 for men ]

Skinfold thickness: Four sites mid-triceps, biceps, subscapular and suprailiac regions. The sum of the measurements should be less than 40 mm in boys and 50 mm in girls.

Waist circumference and waist-hip ratio: At the mid point between the lower border of the rib cage and the iliac crest. There is an increased risk of metabolic complications for men with a waist circumference~ 102 cm, and women with a waist circumference~ 88 cm. A high WHR (> 1.0 in men and> 0.85 in women) indicates abdominal fat accumulation.

questions.text: Triad of non-gonococcal urethritis, arthritis, and conjunctivitis is seen in _________
questions.solution:
• Reiter’s syndrome is a Triad of non-gonococcal urethritis, arthritis, and conjunctivitis.
  • MC organism causing non-gonococcal urethritis is Chlamydia trachomatis.

About other Options:


(b) Ritter’s Disease also known as pemphigus neonatorum or Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS) is a dermatological condition caused by Staphylococcus aureus.

questions.text: Romana’s sign is seen in infection with which of the following pathogen?
questions.solution:
Inoculation of the parasite T. cruzi in conjunctiva causes unilateral, painless oedema of periocular tissues in the eye, as shown in the image below, called as Romana’s sign.

  • This is classically seen in acute Chagas disease.
  • Acute Chagas disease occurs soon after infection and may last for 1 to 4 months.

Some additional points:

  • Chagoma is a typical lesion occurring in acute chagas disease at the site of inoculation.
  • Chronic chagas disease is characterized by Mega oesophagus, Mega colon and Myopathy (MMM).

 

Note:

Trypanosoma rangeli is nonpathogenic.

questions.text: Which one of the following anesthetic agents shows the Robin Hood phenomenon?
questions.solution:
Robin Hood or reverse steal phenomenon is seen with thiopentone.

Thiopentone constricts the cerebral vasculature, causing a decrease in cerebral blood flow, cerebral blood volume, and intracranial pressure. However, this vasoconstriction occurs only in normal areas. The blood vessels in the ischemic area remain dilated due to ischemia-induced vasomotor paralysis and are unaffected by thiopentone. This leads to redistribution of blood flow from normal to ischemic areas in the brain. This is called the Robin Hood phenomenon.

questions.text: Knudson's two-hit hypothesis describes the occurrence of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Knudson's two-hit hypothesis describes the occurrence of retinoblastoma.

Knudson's hypothesis can be stated as follows:

  • Two mutations (hits), involving both alleles of RB are required to produce retinoblastoma.
  • In familial retinoblastoma, one of the pair of alleles of RB1 is mutated in all the cells of the body. When a further mutagenic event ("second hit" according to the "two-hit" hypothesis proposed by Knudson) affects the second allele, the cell may then undergo malignant transformation. A large majority of these children develop bilateral and multifocal tumors.
  • In sporadic cases, both RB alleles must undergo somatic mutation in the same retinoblast (two hits).

Familial retinoblastoma patients also have a predisposition to non-ocular cancers because of the presence of the mutation in all cells, such as pinealoblastoma (usually before the age of 5 years), osteosarcomas, soft tissue sarcomas, and melanomas.

Note:

Trilateral retinoblastoma = Pinealoblastoma + Bilateral retinoblastoma

questions.text: A 9-year-old child presents with recurrent transient ischemic attacks and occasional headaches. Cerebral X-ray angiography is done as shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and cerebral X-ray angiography image shows the "puff of smoke" appearance, characteristic of Moyamoya disease.

Moyamoya disease is a rare, non-inflammatory, progressive, occlusive disease affecting the large intracranial arteries. In this condition, the lenticulostriate arteries form a rich collateral circulation around the occlusive lesions, creating the "puff of smoke" angiographic appearance, referred to as "moyamoya" in Japanese. 

It exhibits a bimodal age distribution, with onset typically occurring in the first and fourth decades of life. The most common presentation is stroke or transient ischemic attacks (TIA), with the nature of these events differing by age group. In childhood, ischemic events are predominant, while hemorrhagic manifestations are frequent in adults.

questions.text: Where is Rasmussen’s aneurysm seen?
questions.solution:
The aneurysm of the pulmonary artery within the tuberculous cavity is called Rasmussen’s aneurysm.

Rasmussen's aneurysm is an inflammatory pseudo-aneurysmal dilatation. This occurs during the healing of the tuberculous cavity. There is a progressive weakening of the arterial wall, in which both the tunica adventitia and media are replaced by granulation tissue. This is gradually replaced by fibrin resulting in thinning of the arterial wall leading to pseudoaneurysm formation.

Rupture of Rasmussen's aneurysm can cause massive hemoptysis. CT angiography plays an important role in locating the aneurysm.

Most cases of massive hemoptysis arise from the bronchial arterial tree because of high pressure within bronchial arteries. Even when a pulmonary aneurysm is present, the actual bleeding may be from the bronchial artery, rather than from the pulmonary artery itself.

questions.text: What is the process of reconversion of lactate formed in the muscles and RBC’s, back into glucose inside the liver called?
questions.solution:
The process of reconversion of lactate formed in the muscles and RBCs, back into glucose inside the liver is called Cori's cycle.

Lactic acid is a metabolic byproduct formed after glycolysis in tissues such as the skeletal muscles and RBCs. The lactate so formed is transported into the liver and kidney. Here, it gets reconverted back into glucose. This entire process is called Cori’s cycle or the glucose–lactate cycle.

Cahill cycle is also called as glucose–alanine cycle. In the fasting state, there is a significant output of alanine from skeletal muscle obtained from glycolysis of muscle glycogen. Alanine is derived from the transamination of pyruvate obtained from glycolysis. Alanine is then exported to the liver where it undergoes transamination again back to pyruvate and enters gluconeogenesis.

Note: Pentose phosphate pathway is otherwise known as Warburg-Dickens-Horecker Cycle.

Related Pearl: Transport of ammonia in blood (Cahill and Cori cycle)

questions.text: Electron microscopic picture of which of the following conditions is shown below?
questions.solution:
The given electron microscopy image shows tennis racket shaped Birbeck granules. These granules are characteristic of Langerhans cell histiocytosis.

These granules are pentalaminar tubules with dilated terminal ends. This gives a characteristic tennis racket appearance on electron microscopy. They contain the protein langerin (CD207).

The image given below shows the Birbeck granules as seen on electron microscopy.

On peripheral smear, the proliferating Langerhans cells are characterised by:

  • Abundant vacuolated cytoplasm
  • Vesicular nuclei containing linear grooves or folds - coffee bean nuclei

The image given below shows Langerhans cells with coffee bean nuclei and moderately abundant pale cytoplasm mixed with a few eosinophils.

Note: Tennis racket cells in light microscopy seen in sarcoma botryoides.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about Russel-Silver Syndrome?
questions.solution:
Russel silver syndrome is a growth disorder characterized by slow growth before and after birth. Hence, it presents as Low birth weight, not macrosomia.

Features:

Normal Head growth is present but affected children are thin and have a poor appetite.

Low birth weight and failure to thrive are often associated.  

Parent-specific differences in gene expression are caused due to genomic imprinting.

Hence Uniparental disomy can cause it.

Genes in chromosome 7 and 11 are involved in this.

questions.text: Tigroid white matter on MR imaging is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Tigroid white matter on MR imaging is seen in Pelizaeus-Merzbacher disease.

It is a rare, X-linked recessive disorder characterized by central nervous system dysmyelination.

The proteolipid protein gene (PLP1) is affected, leading to the failure of axon myelination by oligodendrocytes in the central nervous system.

Clinical Features:

  • Nystagmus
  • Developmental delay
  • Psychomotor delay
  • Seizure
  • Stridor
  • Feeding difficulties
  • Ataxia
  • Hypotonia progressing to spasticity.

The degree of dysmyelination is correlated with the severity of the clinical manifestations.

Genetic analysis can confirm the diagnosis. MRI shows a lack of myelination and MR spectroscopy reveals aberrant N-acetyl aspartate (NAA) and choline concentrations that reflect axonal and myelination abnormalities.

Unlike other demyelinating leukodystrophies such as metachromatic leukodystrophy and adrenoleukodystrophy, where myelin is formed but subsequently destroyed, PMD shows a failure of myelin formation.

questions.text: Which of the following is known as mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome?
questions.solution:
Kawasaki disease is also known as mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome.

Kawasaki disease is an acute febrile illness occurring in children aged 4 years or younger. It is usually self- limiting. This vasculitis affects large to medium-sized vessels and even small vessels. 

It is also known as mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome because it can present with non-purulent conjunctivitis, oral erythema, edema of the hands and feet, desquamative rash, and cervical lymph node enlargement.

It has a predilection for coronary artery involvement and is the leading cause of acquired heart disease in children. Untreated patients may develop coronary artery ectasia or aneurysms, leading to rupture or thrombosis, myocardial infarction, and sudden death.

Espundia is the muco-cutaneous variant of Leishmaniasis

questions.text: Fincham’s test is done for ________
questions.solution:
Fincham's test is used to distinguish whether the colored halos are due to cataract or glaucoma.

Different causes of colored halos are:

  • Cataract
  • Acute congestive glaucoma
  • Mucopurulent conjunctivitis

Fincham’s test

  • During this test, a glaucomatous halo remains intact, while a halo due to cataract is broken up into segments.
  • In conjunctivitis, halos can be eliminated by irrigating the discharge.

Clinical features of cataract

  • Blurring of vision
  • Diminution of vision
  • Polyopia, commonly seen in incipient cataract
  • Glare
  • Colored halos

questions.text: Hematemesis and melena are the usual presenting features of bleeding located _________
questions.solution:
Hematemesis and melena are the usual presenting features of upper gastrointestinal bleeding. Upper GI bleeding is derived from a source proximal to the ligament of Treitz.

The ligament of Treitz is part of the duodenojejunal junction and forms the line of demarcation for gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding.

Upper GI bleeding refers to bleeding proximal to the ligament of Treitz, and lower GI bleeding refers to bleeding distal to the ligament of Treitz.

questions.text: Which of the following structures do the Sharpey's fibers connect?

  • Bone - tether the periosteum to the underlying bone. 
  • Teeth - connect the cementum to the periosteum of the alveolar bone (tooth socket).

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with numbness of both hands. He was asked to perform the test demonstrated below. What is this test?
questions.solution:
The test performed in the image is Roos test. It is also referred to as the elevated arm stress test (EAST). It is a provocative test for the diagnosis of thoracic outlet syndrome.

For this test, the patient abducts the shoulders to 90 degrees and flexes the elbow to 90 degrees. The patient is made to open and close the hand repeatedly for three minutes. The test is positive if the patient is unable to complete the test or experiences cramping, pain, numbness, on the affected side.

Related Pearl: Thoracic outlet syndrome and its tests:

Thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS) is a neurovascular syndrome caused due to the compression of the lower trunk of brachial plexus (C8 and T1) and subclavian vessels in the thoracic outlet between the clavicle, the first rib, and scalene muscles.

Clinical features due to compression of:

  • Brachial plexus: Pain and paraesthesia along the ulnar aspect of the arm.
  • Subclavian vessels: Cyanosis, cold fingers, pallor and Raynaud's phenomenon.

Provocative tests: Adson's test, Halstead's maneuver, Wright's test, Roos test.

Adson’s test: The examiner locates the radial pulse while arm is held in extension, external rotation, and slight abduction. The patient is instructed to take a deep breath and turn head towards the test arm while extending the neck. This manoeuvre will tense the anterior and middle scalenes. If there is outlet obstruction, the radial pulse will get diminished or absent on that side. 

Halstead maneuver (reverse Adson's): The examiner palpates the radial pulse and applies downward traction on the tested extremity while the patient’s neck is hyperextended and rotated to the opposite side. Diminished or absent pulse indicates a positive test.

Wright’s hyperabduction test: The examiner palpates the radial pulse and hyper-abducts the arm. The patient takes a deep breath and may rotate or extend his neck for additional effect. Absence of pulse indicates a positive test.

Roos test: The patient abducts the shoulders to 90 degrees and flexes the elbow to 90 degrees. The patient is made to open and close the hand repeatedly for three minutes. The test is positive if the patient is unable to complete the test or experiences cramping, pain, numbness, on the affected side.

questions.text: Bouchard’s nodes are seen in?

choices.text: Both proximal and distal interphalangeal joints

questions.solution:
Bouchard’s nodes are seen in the proximal interphalangeal joint. 

Heberden nodes are the knobby appearance of DIP. They are formed due to the formation of osteophytes and tissue swelling. 

They are the signs of osteoarthritis in hands. 

Osteoarthritis is the most common cause of chronic knee pain in individuals of age >45 years. In the early phases, there is episodic joint pain following overactive use of the diseased joint. As the disease progresses, there is continuous pain and may be associated with stiffness of the affected joint. Morning stiffness if present, is usually brief for around 30 minutes.

The joints involved in osteoarthritis are: 

  • Distal and proximal interphalangeal joints (DIP, PIP)
  • First carpometacarpal joint (base of the thumb)
  • Hip and knee joints
  • First metatarsophalangeal joint (MTP)
  • Cervical and lumbosacral spine

On examination, there is tenderness in the joint. A crepitus is felt on joint movement and the range of movements is painfully restricted. Bouchard's and Heberden's nodes may be palpated in PIP and DIP respectively.

Characteristic features of osteoarthritis seen on plain X-ray are:

  • Marginal osteophyte formation
  • Localized joint space narrowing
  • Sclerosis of the underlying bone
  • Subchondral bone cysts

questions.text:
McNaughten's rule falls under which Section?

BNS- Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita
BNSS- Bharatiya Nagarik Suraksha Sanhita
questions.solution:
McNaughten's rule falls under Section 22 of the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita (IPC 84). 

It states, "A person of unsound mind is not liable for an act."

Defect: In Mc Naughthen’s rule, only intellectual factors are considered but emotions, delusion, and control of impulses are ignored.

Related Pearl: BNS section 22, M'Naghten's rule

M'Naghten's rule, BNS 22 (Previously - Section 84 IPC):  Criminal responsibility of the insane.

Nothing is an offence which is done by a person who, at the time of doing it, by reason of unsoundness of mind, is incapable of knowing the nature of the act, or that he is doing what is either wrong or contrary to law.

questions.text: An infant presents with copious bilious vomiting and abdominal distension on the 5th day of life. He had not passed meconium for the first 3 days after birth. An abdominal radiograph shows the presence of dilated bowel loops. What is the gold standard investigation for the given condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of Hirschsprung's disease. A rectal biopsy is the gold standard for the diagnosis of Hirschsprung’s disease.

A rectal biopsy 2 cm above the dentate line is the ideal area for a biopsy.

Hirschsprung’s disease is a developmental disorder characterized by the absence of ganglion cells in the myenteric (Auerbach) plexus and submucosal (Meissner) plexus. Most infants present with abdominal distention and bilious emesis with failure to pass meconium within the first 24 hours of life.

The initial investigation is a contrast enema. The area between the dilated and contracted segments is referred to as the transition zone. The affected part shows the absence of ganglion cells and hypertrophy of nerve trunks in the rectal biopsy.

Other investigations for Hirschsprung’s disease include:

  • Water-soluble contrast enema - shows the presence of contracted aganglionic rectum, transition zone, and a dilated normally innervated colon.
  • Anorectal manometry - shows the failure of the relaxation of the internal anal sphincter.

 Definitive surgeries for Hirschsprung disease are as follows:

  • Swenson procedure, where aganglionic bowel is removed and a coloanal anastomosis is performed.
  • Duhamel procedure, where the aganglionic rectal stump is left in place and the ganglionated normal colon is pulled posterior.
  • Soave procedure, where endorectal mucosal dissection is done within the aganglionic distal rectum. The ganglionated normal colon is pulled through the remnant muscular cuff, and a coloanal anastomosis is performed.
